div.p: Venerable, highly and well-learned sir, my willing service to you at all times, etc. beforehand. On the 15th of this month, I sent you the latest from Winterthur, also to the captain in Wil, to inform me by whom he sent the letters and the package from Rottenstein via Zurich; for I have no peace until I hear that you have received them; for without a doubt, both women are very eager for a response. The captain has assured me that he has arranged it; kindly ask to inform me via courier. There is a messenger who goes to Nuremberg, well known to Mr. Schlüsselberger. If my honorable Mr. Walther has received the letters from Augsburg, I would like to know. I will not send anything more to the captain.

I have little news, except the following: Duke of Alba is said to have lost up to 5000 men before Haarlem, 8 ships, including 5 laden from Antwerp, were sunk, the port thus damaged, that it cannot be cleared for a long time.
In Amsterdam, due to the munitions, the Spaniards have slaughtered over 8000 citizens.

Before La Rochelle, the defeat follows; may God help the Prince of Condé; he will have to leave. The Lord of Chamagne, who was governor in Burgundy, has passed away, so I know of no more renowned commander who could lead an army of mercenaries. There is great famine throughout the land; in Lyon, the grain costs 65β, which is over 2 francs, almost a Constance quarter. There is fear and distress; the pious are dead in body, the others kill them in soul and body. I will not forget the poor. So my request is, if it is not too burdensome, to find out if there is a cabinetmaker among you, a native of Zurich, named Rudolf Dowys, who worked with noble wood in Bologna, Italy, years ago; whether he is still alive or dead, and if he is married; it would be a favor to me, so do not spare me. Greet all your people for me. God's grace be with you, yours, and all of us. Amen.
Your willing servant always, Hans Liner.
To the venerable and well-learned Mr. Heinrich Bullinger the Elder, faithful servant of the church in Zurich, my honorable, beloved sir in Zurich.
